bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Melvin D. Brewer, November 29, 1940

div1.p: Hench urges Brewer to search for the missing autographed photographs of Moran and Kissinger. He appreciates receiving additional memorabilia from the Lazear memorial event.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Melvin D. Brewer, November 29, 1940
div1.opener:
November 29, 1940
Mr. M. D. Brewer
Washington and Jefferson College
Washington, Pa.
My dear Mr. Brewer:
div1.p:
I am a little disturbed about my missing photographs of Moran and
Kissinger. Perhaps I should be sending this letter to Dr. Hutchison rather
than to you, but I am sending a carbon copy to him and Miss Hough. It was
my distinct recollection that I had included, with the various other photographs,
my own autographed photos of Moran and Kissinger. When I was in Washington, I
mentioned this to Miss Hough. She hesitated a moment and then said, “Yes, I
believe they are in the folder with the other photographs.”

After receiving your letter yesterday, last night I looked through all
my photographs and correspondence. I found the two empty folders in which I had
had the photographs and found a memorandum with the empty folders which read, “My
autographed photos of Moran and Kissinger sent to Dr. Hutchison.” My secretary
has a copy of the letter sent to Dr. Hutchison, under the date of October 5, at
which time I sent him the various photographs which you returned to me, and the
following paragraph:

“I enclose with them a photograph of Moran and one of Kissinger, made out
to me. But the autographs are such that they will not interfere with your publicity
purposes..... I am very proud of the ones of Moran and Kissinger to me, and I sin-
cerely hope you will ask your photographer to take special care of them and if
possible, return not only them but also the others, or save them until I come.”

Therefore, I am afraid the burden of proof is on you, as they were all
sent together. I am sure you will find them. You may have, in the meantime,
received ones directly from Moran and Kissinger, and used them. Therefore, I
suspect that my photographs are still somewhere in Dr. Hutchison's office. Naturally,
I am anxious not to have them lost, but fortunately, as the two men are still living,
if they are lost, it isn't irreparable, but I would be a little embarrassed to write
and ask them for another until more of a search has been made for them.

Thank you very kindly for your promise to send me copies of the additional
photographs taken by another photographer. I shall be very glad to have them. I
shall also be very glad to see the souvenir booklet which you are making. I am sure
it will be very nice. If possible, I should like to have a dozen copies, to place
in the hands of the people who have been helping me in my historical researches.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
